content: The "Conservation Program Improvement Act of 2017" is also known as the Conservation Reserve Program. The Conservation Program Improvement Act of 2017, also known as the Conservation Reserve Program, includes amendments to extend Section 1231(a) to 2023 and modify enrollment criteria for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. The Secretary is required to enroll and maintain acreage in a specified manner during this period. The Conservation Program Improvement Act of 2017 extends Section 1231(a) to 2023 and modifies enrollment criteria for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. The Secretary must enroll and maintain acreage in the conservation reserve according to target acreage for each State, calculated based on past enrollment numbers. The Conservation Program Improvement Act of 2017 extends Section 1231(a) to 2023 and modifies enrollment criteria for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. It includes restrictions on land planted to trees, where base acres on a farm enrolled in the conservation reserve exceeding available cropland will result in a permanent reduction of base acres. MODIFICATIONS TO CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROGRAMS: Title XII of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include new conservation provisions under Subtitle F. This includes changes to conservation easement programs. Eligible owners or operators may now terminate contracts without penalty within a 3-year period. The term "covered program" includes various conservation programs such as the conservation reserve program, farmable wetland program, special conservation reserve enhancement program, agricultural conservation easement program, healthy forests reserve program, and similar programs determined by the Secretary. These programs are established under different sections and acts. The Secretary can allow modifications to land enrolled in a covered program for water management, maintenance, wildlife habitat management, etc., with approval from the State department of natural resources and the technical committee. Land can also be exchanged for land with equal or greater conservation values as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary can approve modifications to land enrolled in a covered program for practical administration and management purposes without adversely affecting its established functions and values. Any modification or exchange must not result in a net loss of enrolled acreage and exchanged land must meet all program requirements. Costs associated with requesting a modification or exchange under a covered program include appraisal, repayment of restoration costs, property boundary survey, and preparation and recording of any exchange. The real estate practices of any exchange include requirements for title approval, subordination of liens, and recording of amended warranty easement deed, along with applicable recording and legal fees.
